title: Meta
description: At Meta, I'm one of the core engineers working on Anonymous Credential Service. ACS leverages blind signatures and other cryptographic primitivies to enable de-identified authentication at scale, serving hundreds of thousands of requests per second. One of the coolest experiences I had at Meta was that I co-presented ACS at the Systems@Scale 2022 Conference, and helped write about it on the Meta Engineering Blog. We actually even received media coverage link and link)!

title: Learn & Verify
description: I joined the UC Berkeley Learn & Verify Research Lab under Professor Sanjit Seshia for the duration of my Master's research. I worked on PSec (a programming language for creating secure distributed systems) and was mentored by Professor Sanjit Seshia, Professor Pramod Subramanyan, and Ankush Desai. I was briefly involved in the lab during undergrad as well where I created an Intel SGX-based Password Manager. (Google Scholar link)

title: MDB
description: I designed, developed, and deployed Android apps with my classmates during my time in the Mobile Developers of Berkeley club. My biggest apps (and ventures in entrepreneurship) were YearBook and NearMe. One cool experience was that our YearBook team was accepted to Free Ventures (startup accelerator) and we pitched to VCs such as Sequoia and General Catalyst.

title: Facebook
description: I interned on the e2e authorization team at Facebook. My intern project was to create a new mechanism of granting ACL access that reduced our attack surface by issuing temporary access and renewed based on calculated utilization threshold.

title: Via
description: I co-founded The Via App to help solve the problem of reliable contact synchronization. This was my first entrepreneurial experience and I learned how to manage a development team, iterate on business strategies and product design, and hustle to get our very first customers. We decided to sunset the project after ~2 years.

title: Workday
description: I interned on the Workday Next Team and worked on a verifiable credentials blockchain application. I implemented security protocols and leveraged mobile hardware enclaves to create a MVP Android Blockchain Wallet for the protocol. As part of this project, I contributed to an open source crypto library and merged a PR!

title: Yahoo
description: I interned on the Tripod Pixel Team (Flickr backend) and learned how to write server code in a production environment. I learned Java Spring and implemented a unique media ID generator REST microservice. I additionally conducted and presented a data analysis of cost vs performance of different compression algorithms, and my recommended algorithm is now actually the default for photo compression.
